#Text=Janbirdi al-Ghazali
#Text=Warning :
#Text=Page using Template : Infobox officeholder with unknown parameter " religion " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .
#Text=Janbirdi al-Ghazali

#Text=( Arabic : جان بردي الغزالي‎ ; Jān-Birdi al-Ghazāli ; died 1521 ) was the first governor of Damascus Province under the Ottoman Empire from February 1519 until his death in February 1521 . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Viceroy of Hama and Governor of Damascus
#Text=Al-Ghazali was originally the na'ib or " viceroy " of Hama under the Mamluk Sultanate of Egypt in the early 16th century .
#Text=When the Ottomans invaded Mamluk Syria , Janbirdi fought alongside the latter at the Battle of Marj Dabiq in 1516 , leading the assault on Ottoman sultan Selim I ' s army in Gaza .
#Text=Al-Ghazali was wounded during that confrontation .
#Text=After the Mamluk defeat , he retreated to Cairo with his army where he took part in the defense of the city from incoming Ottoman forces .
#Text=The Ottomans again defeated the Mamluks and conquered Egypt and Syria . [ 3 ]
#Text=Al-Ghazali then joined the Mamluk governor of Aleppo in defecting to the Ottomans and severed allegiance with Mamluk sultan Qansuh al-Ghawri . [ 4 ]
#Text=Selim I was reportedly impressed by al-Ghazali 's loyalty to his superiors and in a bid to have him serve under the Ottomans , [ 3 ]
#Text=Selim appointed him as governor of Damascus in February 1519 . [ 5 ]
#Text=At the time , Damascus Province encompassed much of the Levant , including much of central and southern Syria , the Syrian coastline , Palestine , Transjordan and Lebanon .
#Text=He paid an annual tribute of 230,000 dinars to the Ottoman sultan . [ 3 ]
#Text=As governor , he was in charge of safeguarding the pilgrim caravan destined to make hajj in the Hejaz for the pilgrim route from Damascus to Aqaba in southern Transjordan .
#Text=In order to do this successfully , he subjugated the Turkmen nomads in the area .
#Text=After two years , he managed to have those same Turkmen tribes protecting the pilgrims .
#Text=By 1520 , hajj caravans were traveling without incident . [ 1 ]
#Text=In line with Ottoman state policy at the time , al-Ghazali embarked on major development projects in Damascus .
#Text=Having been appointed the nazir or " supervisor " of Damascus 's main waqf , he had the Umayyad Mosque repaired and redecorated .
#Text=He also had a number of other mosques , schools and canals rebuilt and repaired .
#Text=Supervisors of madrasas ( " religious schools " ) who were deemed negligent were stripped of their position and their school buildings restored . [ 2 ]

column1: #Text=Revolt against Ottomans
#Text=Following the succession of Süleyman the Magnificent to the sultanate after Selim 's death in 1520 , al-Ghazali revolted against the Ottoman state .
#Text=He sought to restore Mamluk suzerainty , declaring himself " sultan " or al-Malik al-Ashraf ( " the most noble king " ) .

#Text=He banned preachers in mosques from upholding the Ottoman sultan 's name in Friday prayers , purged Ottoman officials and soldiers from Syria , and banned Ottoman dress by the province 's citizens .
#Text=After he declared himself sultan , the cities of Tripoli , Hama , and Hims joined his rebellion . [ 6 ]

#Text=After failed attempts to enlist the support of Shah Ismail of the Safavid Empire and Kha'ir Bey , the Ottoman governor of Egypt , [ 7 ] he nonetheless raised an army and set out to conquer Aleppo .
#Text=The residents of Aleppo supported the Ottoman sultanate , however , and resisted al-Ghazali 's efforts .
#Text=His army besieged the city for 15 days , during which over 200 residents and Ottoman soldiers were killed , but to no avail .
#Text=He withdrew to Damascus soon after to rally his forces . [ 6 ]
#Text=In February 1521 , the Ottoman Army arrived at the outskirts of Damascus where al-Ghazali 's troops confronted them .
#Text=His army was swiftly defeated and he was executed .
#Text=The Ottoman army sent al-Ghazali 's severed head to Süleyman as a trophy .
#Text=The Ottomans also proceeded to sack Damascus , killing 3,000 residents , and destroying the town quarters as well as nearby villages . [ 6 ]
#Text=With the deposition of al-Ghazali 's revolt , Mamluk influence in Syria came to an end . [ 6 ]
#Text=The Ottoman contemporary chroniclers report al-Ghazali 's revolt as the first major event of the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent . [ 8 ]
